title: A machine that removes weeds without damaging crops

tasks.task: Drive a combine harvester and operate the associated machinery during harvest.
subtasks: Sit in the operator's seat and control the combine harvester's movements.
Monitor the combine's harvesting process and adjust settings as necessary.
Oversee the movement of the combine through the field.
Adjust the combine's crop pickup and threshing components as needed.
Manage the combine's conveyors and cleaning systems to ensure proper crop flow.
Operate the combine's hydraulic systems to steer and control attachment equipment.
Monitor grain quality and moisture content during combine operation.
Troubleshoot and address any mechanical issues or operator error on the combine.

tasks.task: Load harvested grain into a grain cart or storage facility.
subtasks: Guide the grain cart into position alongside the combine.
Activate the combine's unloading auger or conveyor to transfer grain into the grain cart.
Secure any loose grain at the unloading point to prevent spillage.
Verify correct grain flow direction and grain quality into the cart.
Drive the grain cart to the next storage area or facility.
Offload grain from the cart into storage bins or a grain elevator.
Organize the grain unloading process to minimize operator wait time.

tasks.task: Maintain and clean farming equipment after operation.
subtasks: Inspect the combine for any visible damage or wear during and after operation.
Service the combine's hydraulic systems, checking for leaks and topping up fluids.
Lubricate moving parts and greased points to ensure continued smooth operation.
Check and replace filters, such as air, oil, and hydraulic filters, as needed.
Inspect the combine's electrical systems for any loose connections or malfunctions.
Clean the combine's cab and exterior surfaces to prevent debris buildup.
Properly store and disconnect any auxiliary equipment attached to the combine.

tasks.task: Plan the crop rotation and vegetation control measures for the following season.
subtasks: Assess the current year's crop yield and health to determine next year's planting areas.
Consider soil type, nutrient levels, and pest data when planning rotations.
Research suitable crop types for the planned rotation, considering market demand and climate.
Develop a schedule for planting and harvesting each crop in the rotation.
Arrange for the necessary equipment and supplies, including seed, fertilizer, and pesticides.
Schedule mechanical and chemical treatments for weed, pest, and disease management.
Prepare written plans for crop rotations, including timings and requirements.
Check grain bins for structural integrity and airtight seals.
Clean grain storage bins and remove any leftover grain from the previous season.
Test grain aeration systems to maintain quality during storage.
Verify that cooling systems are operational to prevent moisture damage.
